questions.text: A 6-year-old child complaining of pain and swelling is suspected with supracondylar fracture of right hand (Undisplaced). X-ray of right elbow was not significant. What is the next best step in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Compare with X-ray of left hand

options.label: B
options.text: Immobilisation and above the elbow plaster slab (90 degree flexion)

options.label: C
options.text: Closed reduction with K wire fixation Cast

questions.correct_answer: B. Immobilisation and above the elbow plaster slab (90 degree flexion)

questions.text: What type of displacement is most likely observed in a 60-year-old female patient who presents with pain and swelling in her left wrist after falling on an outstretched hand, and exhibits a dinner fork deformity upon examination?

options.label: A
options.text: Proximal and ventral displacement of radius

options.label: B
options.text: Supination and dorsal displacement of radius

options.label: C
options.text: Proximal and dorsal displacement of ulna

options.label: D
options.text: Proximal and ventral displacement of ulna

questions.correct_answer: B. Supination and dorsal displacement of radius

questions.text: Which nerve is most likely to be damaged in cases of anterior shoulder dislocation?

Match the following fractures with their respective sites. A. Jones fracture B. Bennett's fracture C. March fracture D. Boxer fracture 1. 5th metatarsal 2. 2nd metatarsal 3. 1st metacarpal 4. 5th metacarpal
questions.explanation:
Fracture Type

Features

Treatment

Jones fractures
  • Significant adduction force to the foot with a lifted heel (e.g., sudden direction change)
  • Location of injury: 4th/5th metatarsal articulation

March Fracture
  • A stress fracture commonly seen in runners, involving the metatarsals due to repetitive overuse.
  • The patient's gradual onset of pain and tenderness after increased running
  • X-ray shows no obvious fracture, but a faint periosteal reaction is seen.

Bennett fracture
  • Oblique intra-articular fracture (2 part) of the base of the first metacarpal with subluxation of the metacarpal.
  • It is caused by a longitudinal force applied to the thumb.
  • Treatment:
    • Closed reduction and percutaneous K-wire fixation
    • Open reduction and internal fixation

Boxer's fracture
  • Fracture through the neck of the metacarpal (commonly the 5th metacarpal).
  • Cause: Closed fist hits against a hard object
  • Treatment: Mostly conservative

questions.text: An old lady slipped and fell at home. She was diagnosed with a Colles fracture and managed with a POP cast. What is the correct sequence of reduction of the given fracture?

options.label: A
options.text: Traction, POP, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation

options.label: B
options.text: Traction, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, POP

options.label: C
options.text: Traction, ulnar deviation, palmar flexion, POP

options.label: D
options.text: Palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, traction, POP

questions.correct_answer: B. Traction, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, POP

questions.text: A female patient with a history of fall few months back presents with the deformity shown in the image. Probing into history reveals it was managed with traditional treatment. This deformity is likely to be due to?
Fishtail deformity is seen in fracture of
questions.explanation:
Supracondylar Fractures

Mechanism of injury

Fall on outstretched hand (FOOSH)

Location

Humerus fractures just above the condyles.

Displacements

The distal fragment of the humerus is usually displaced by

  • Posterior shift (Due to Impaction)
  • Posterior Tilt
  • Proximal shift
  • Medial shift/ Tilt
  • Internal rotation

Types
  • Type 1: Undisplaced fracture
  • Type 2: Partially displaced fracture with displacement of only anterior cortex
  • Type 3: Completely displaced anterior and posterior cortex.

Clinical Presentation
  • Severe elbow pain, swelling, deformity, and loss of function may occur, and neurological symptoms like weakness in wrist flexion or the hand of benediction sign may also occur if the median nerve is affected.
  • Unusual posterior prominence of the olecranon in the backward tilt (S-shaped deformity)
  • The skin around the fracture has a dimpled appearance (Dimple sign)

X-ray Findings
  • Three bony parts relationship is maintained.
  • Fat Pad or Sail sign: A translucent shadow-like appearance representing anterior and posterior fat pads.
  • Disturbed teardrop sign: An abnormal appearance of the fat pad, suggesting the presence of an injury, such as a fracture or joint effusion.

 

  • Fishtail sign: The ends of the proximal fragment are slightly widened and serrated, resembling a fishtail.
  • Crescent sign: The normal radiolucent gap of the elbow joint is replaced by a crescent-shaped shadow from the capitulum overlapping the olecranon, indicating varus or valgus tilt of the distal fragment.

Management

Based on the type of fracture

  • Undisplaced fracture: Immobilisation in above-elbow plaster slab with the elbow in 90-degree flexion.
  • Displaced fractures
    • Closed reduction with percutaneous K-wire fixation. (for Type 2 fracture)
    • Open reduction internal fixation with K-wire. (for Type 3 fracture)
  • In Late presentation with swelling
    • Dunlop traction (skin)
    • Smith traction (skeletal)

Complications
  • Early complications
    • Vascular injury (commonly Brachial artery)
    • Nerve injury (commonly Anterior Interosseous nerve)
  • Delayed complications
    • Cubitus varus or Gunstock deformity (Malunion)
    • Volkmann's Ischemia and compartment syndrome.
    • Elbow stiffness
    • Myositis ossificans.

questions.text: What is the most specific test used to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Carpal tunnel syndrome

Definition

Compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist

Symptoms
  • Numbness, tingling in thumb, index, and middle fingers
  • Pain in hand and wrist
  • Weakness in grip
  • Symptoms often worse at night and improve during the day.
  • Advanced cases may lead to constant symptoms, hand weakness, clumsiness, and muscle atrophy.

Structures Affected
  • Median Nerve: Compressed within the carpal tunnel, leading to symptoms and signs.
  • Flexor Tendons: The nine flexor tendons passing through the carpal tunnel can become inflamed, further compressing the median nerve.

Structures Spared
  • Thenar Eminence: Sensory loss generally spares this area because its nerve (palmar sensory cutaneous nerve) bypasses the carpal tunnel.

Clinical Signs
  • Weakness: Notable weakness in thumb abduction and opposition.
  • Atrophy: Possible atrophy of the thenar eminence in advanced cases.
  • Sensory Loss: Loss typically affects the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the fourth digit).

Causes
  • Idiopathic- commonest cause
  • Inflammatory causes- Rheumatoid arthritis, wrist osteoarthritis
  • Post-traumatic causes- Bone thickening after a Colles' fracture
  • Endocrine causes- Myxoedema, Acromegaly

Diagnostic Tests
  • Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS) - primary diagnostic test
  • Electromyography (EMG)
  • Carpal Compression Test/ Durkan test: Diagnostic test. Positive if pain/paresthesias occur during pressure application over the carpal tunnel.
  • Phalen Test: Positive if pain/paresthesias arise during wrist flexion. (Option B ruled out)
  • Tinel Test: Positive if tapping over the carpal tunnel elicits symptoms. (Option C ruled out)

Treatment
  • Conservative: Wrist splinting, NSAIDs, activity modification
  • Corticosteroid injections
  • Surgical: Carpal tunnel release (for severe or refractory cases)

questions.text: Identify the following fracture:
questions.explanation:
Monteggia fracture

Site

Fracture of the proximal third of the ulna is accompanied by a radial head dislocation.

Cause

Fall on an outstretched hand

Mechanism

Complications

  • Nerve injury (Posterior Interosseous Nerve)
  • Malunion
  • Non-union
  • Cubitus valgus.
  • Radio ulnar synostosis (Type 4 Monteggia Fracture)
  • Myositis Ossificans.

questions.text: A 23 year old male epileptic patient presented with pain in right shoulder region. Examination revealed that right upper limb was abducted and externally rotated and the movements could not be performed. Which of the following is most likely diagnosed
questions.explanation:
Aspects

Anterior dislocation

Posterior dislocation

(Option D)

Inferior dislocation

(Option B)

Frequency

Most common

Not very common

Rare

Mechanism of Injury

Fall on an outstretched hand with an abducted and externally rotated shoulder.

Occurs during seizures or convulsions.

  • A fall onto a flexed, adducted arm.
  • A direct impact to the anterior aspect of the shoulder.
  • A fall onto an outstretched hand.
  • Also called luxatio erecta.
  • Result from a severe hyper-abduction force.

Clinical presentation

Pain, swelling and movement restriction.

Tests

Duga’s test, Hamilton ruler test and Regimental badge test.

Callaway’s test and Regimental badge test

Bryant’s test

Arm Position

Abduction and external rotation

Adduction and internal rotation

Arm locked in hyperabduction with the hand positioned above the head.

X-ray Findings
  • The humeral head is displaced anteriorly and inferiorly, often under the coracoid process ("subcoracoid" position).
  • "Hill-Sachs lesion" (compression fracture on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head).

 
  • The humeral head is displaced posteriorly, appearing closer to the scapula.
  • ‘Light bulb sign’(humeral head appears rounded due to internal rotation).
  • ‘Rim sign’ (widening of the glenohumeral joint space).
  • ‘Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion’ (compression fracture on the anteromedial humeral head).

 

The humeral head is displaced inferiorly below the glenoid cavity.

 

Management

Reduction techniques:

  • Kocher's method (Most commonly used)
  • Hippocrates method
  • Stimson’s technique

Reduction and immobility, followed by active exercises.


 
  • Closed reduction
  • Open reduction if soft tissue injuries are present
  • Re-examination after reduction to avoid neurovascular injuries.

Complications
  • Early:
    • Neurovascular injuries
    • Rotator cuff tear
  • Delayed:
    • Recurrence
    • Stiffness
    • Unreduced dislocation
  • Recurrence
  • Unreduced dislocation
  • Neurovascular injuries
  • Recurrence
  • Unreduced dislocation

Anterior Shoulder dislocation

Subtypes
  • Subglenoid: The humeral head lies below the glenoid fossa.
  • Subclavicular: The humeral head is displaced beneath the clavicle.
  • Intrathoracic: The humeral head dislocates into the thoracic cavity, which is rare.
  • Subcoracoid: The humeral head lies below the coracoid process.

Clinical findings
  • Loss of the deltoid contour (loss of shoulder roundness)
  • The shoulder is extended, abducted and externally rotated.

Clinical tests
  • Duga’s test is the inability to touch the opposite shoulder.
  • Hamilton ruler test is where the gap between the ruler and the arm is lost.
  • Callaway’s test is increased girth of the axilla on the dislocated side.
  • Bryant’s Test is where the anterior axillary fold is displaced downward on the affected side.
  • Regiment batch sign is loss of sensation due to axillary nerve damage.

Imaging
  • X-ray reveals that the humeral head is displaced anteriorly and inferiorly, often under the coracoid process ("subcoracoid" position)
  • An MRI is necessary to assess soft-tissue injuries and identify Bankart and Hill-Sachs lesions, which are complications of shoulder dislocations and increase the risk of recurrence due to joint instability.

Management
  • Kocher's method (Most common method) is the reduction by traction, external rotation, adduction, and medial rotation.
  • In Hippocrates' method, the surgeon pulls the semi-abducted arm firmly while using his foot in the axilla as a fulcrum to reduce the dislocation.
  • Stimson’s technique is the reduction by applying weight for traction, using the body as counter traction.

questions.text: Three point bony relationship has a diagnostic value in:
A 25 year old man fell down while running. He tried to sustain the fall on his elbow resulting in the injury shown below.What will be the appropriate management of the following fracture?

options.label: C
options.text: Close reduction with Tension band wiring

options.label: D
options.text: Immobilization of elbow, Above elbow plaster slab with 30 degree flexion

questions.correct_answer: D. Immobilization of elbow, Above elbow plaster slab with 30 degree flexion

questions.text: The diagnosis of the given image
Postmenopausal woman slipped and fell down on an outstretched hand in the washroom. X-ray of her distal forearm is given below. Diagnose the following condition?
questions.explanation:
Fracture Name

Characteristic Findings

Sites Involved

Special History

Colles

Fracture

Dorsal displacement of the distal radius.

Distal radius

Falling on an outstretched hand

Smith's

Fracture

Volar displacement of the distal radius.

Distal radius

Falling on a flexed wrist

Monteggia

Fracture

Proximal ulnar shaft fracture with radial head dislocation.

Proximal ulna, radial head

Direct blow to the ulna or forearm

Galeazzi

Fracture

Distal radial shaft fracture with distal radioulnar joint dislocation.

Distal radius, radioulnar joint

Fall on an outstretched hand with an ulnar deviation

questions.text: Identify the given fracture?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A: Colles Fractu

Definition Colles Fracture is a type of distal radius fracture characterized by a break at the distal end of the radius bone in the forearm. It often involves dorsal displacement and angulation of the distal fragment. Named after the Irish surgeon Abraham Colles.
Epidemiology - Most common type of wrist fracture in adults, particularly in the elderly population. - Often associated with falls onto an outstretched hand.
Mechanism of Injury - Typically occurs due to a fall on an outstretched hand with the wrist extended. - Axial loading on the radius leads to the characteristic fracture pattern.
Clinical Presentation - Deformity: Dorsal displacement and "dinner fork" or "bayonet" deformity may be visible. - Pain: Localized pain at the site of the fracture. - Swelling: Immediate swelling around the wrist.
Radiographic Features - Dorsal Tilt: On X-rays, dorsal displacement and dorsal tilt of the distal fragment are characteristic. - Radial Shortening: Shortening of the radius may also be observed.
Classification - Extra-articular (Type I): Fracture occurs just above the wrist joint. - Partial Articular (Type II): Fracture extends into the joint but does not involve the joint surface. - Complete Articular (Type III): Fracture extends into the joint and involves the joint surface.
Treatment - Closed Reduction and Casting: Common initial approach, especially for less displaced fractures. - Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF): Considered for more complex or displaced fractures, or cases where closed reduction is not successful.
Complications - Malunion: Improper alignment during healing may lead to deformity. - Nerve or Vascular Injury: Rare but possible, especially in more severe fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about perilunate dislocation ?

options.label: A
options.text: Lunate is dislocated anteriorly but the rest of the carpals remains in position

options.label: B
options.text: Lunate remains in position but rest other dislocate dorsally

options.label: D
options.text: Tavernier's manoeuvre is used for closed reduction

questions.correct_answer: A. Lunate is dislocated anteriorly but the rest of the carpals remains in position
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Lunate is dislocated anteriorly but the rest of th

questions.text: Identify the following device.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Cock-u

Cock-up splint

Immobilizes and supports the wrist in a neutral or slightly extended position. Used for conditions such as carpal tunnel syndrome and wrist sprains.

Colle’s' cast

Circumferential cast used for the treatment of distal radius fractures. Immobilizes the wrist and forearm.

Knuckle bender splint

Finger splint used to provide extension support to the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint of the finger.

Dynamic finger splint

Allows controlled movement of the finger joints while providing support and protection. Used in finger injury rehabilitation and post-surgery.

questions.text: The X-ray image of a patient presented to the casualty is given below. How will you manage this case?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Details
Anatomy Olecranon is part of the proximal ulna and serves as the insertion for the triceps
Mechanism of Injury Direct trauma or fall on outstretched hand with elbow flexed
Clinical Features Pain, swelling, inability to extend the elbow
X-ray Findings Fracture line at the olecranon, often transverse or comminuted
Non-operative Treatment Immobilization in nondisplaced fractures (rare)
Operative Treatment Depends on fracture type:
  Tension band wiring for transverse/simple fractures
  Plating for comminuted or unstable fractures

questions.text: Identify the fracture shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • A fracture of the radial head, the upper part of the radius that articulates with the humerus and ulna at the elbow joint.

Causes
  • Most commonly caused by a fall onto an outstretched hand (FOOSH)
  • Direct trauma or a blow to the elbow
  • MVA (Motor Vehicle Accidents) or sports injuries

Types of Fractures
  • Type I: Non-displaced fracture (usually treated conservatively)
  • Type II: Displaced fracture with a single fragment (may require surgical intervention)
  • Type III: Comminuted (multiple fragments, often requiring surgical reconstruction or replacement)

Symptoms
  • Pain and tenderness at the lateral aspect of the elbow
  • Swelling and bruising around the elbow joint
  • Limited range of motion, with flexion and extension
  • Difficulty supination and pronation

Diagnosis
  • Tenderness, swelling, and limited motion.
  • X-rays: Used to classify the type and displacement of the fracture.
  • CT scan: Used for more complex fractures.

Treatment Options
  • Conservative management: For non-displaced (Type I) fractures.
  • Surgical management: For displaced (Type II) or comminuted (Type III) fractures- radial head fixation, replacement (arthroplasty), or excision.

Complications
  • Loss of elbow range of motion
  • Chronic pain
  • Elbow instability
  • Post-traumatic arthritis
  • Stiffness or deformity of the joint

questions.text: Which of the following fractures can cause a deformity as shown in the image below?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Supracondylar fracture of humeru

questions.text: Linear growth of bone is disturbed when a fracture occurs in which of the following locations?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Epiphyseal

questions.text: Which classification is used for the following fracture, and what is its stage?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Gartland 3

questions.text: Identify the fracture:
questions.explanation:
Depressed Fracture

Comminuted Fracture

Gutter Fracture

(Option D)
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks).
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe.
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.
  • Involves multiple intersecting fracture lines, breaking the bone into several fragments.
  • Caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., vehicular accidents, crushing injuries).
  • It may occur alongside other fractures (e.g., fissured or depressed fractures).
  • Spider web-like patterns on an X-ray are characteristic of comminuted fractures.
  • In severe cases, bone fragments may penetrate the brain or become displaced.
  • A groove or channel is formed in the skull bone, often due to an oblique bullet wound.
  • Frequently associated with comminuted and depressed fractures of the inner skull table.
  • Bone fragments can cause injury to the meninges or brain.

 

Depressed fracture

 

Comminuted fracture

 

Gutter fracture

Ring Fracture

 

Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture)

(Option C)

 

 
  • Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base.
  • Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa.
  • It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose.
  • Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign.
  • It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge.

Caused by:

  • Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine).
  • Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex.
  • Twisting of the head on the spine.
  • Blows to the occiput or chin.

Often caused by side impacts.


 

 

Ring fracture

 

 

Hinge fracture

Fissured Fracture (Linear Fracture)

(Option B)

 

 

Diastatic Fracture (Sutural Fracture)

  • The most common skull fracture accounts for about 70% of cases.
  • Linear cracks may involve the vertex or skull base. It can affect the full thickness of the bone or just the inner/outer layers.
  • The fracture line is irregular and fine, sometimes hard to detect on X-rays. It runs parallel to the compressive force.
  • No depression of bone fragments.
  • Involves the separation of cranial sutures.
  • More common in children.
  • Often occurs with other skull fractures, especially fissured fractures.
  • Commonly seen at the sagittal suture.

Causes:

  • Impact against broad surfaces (e.g., falls or road traffic accidents)
  • Falls on feet or buttocks, transmitting force upwards.

Causes:

  • Blunt trauma to the head.
  • Increased intracranial pressure leads to suture separation.

 

Narrow fissure skull fracture

 

Diastatic Fracture

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy who fell on an outstretched hand is now experiencing pain and swelling at the base of the thumb. Which bone is most likely fractured?
questions.explanation:
Scaphoid fracture

Site

  • Waist of scaphoid (most common)
  • Distal pole (Least common)
  • Proximal pole (high risk for avascular necrosis)

Mechanism of injury

Typically caused by a fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH) with the wrist in dorsiflexion.

Clinical features

  • It is more common in young adults, particularly athletes.
  • Pain and tenderness localised to the anatomical snuffbox (the depression between the tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and the abductor pollicis longus/extensor pollicis brevis).
  • Swelling and reduced range of motion at the wrist.

X-ray

There is a visible fracture line at the waist of the scaphoid, with possible cortical disruption or displacement; avascular necrosis may later appear as sclerosis in the proximal pole.

Management

Immobilisation by scaphoid cast (3-4 months)

Complications

  • Avascular necrosis (more common in the proximal pole)
  • Humpback deformity (displaced Scaphoid fracture)
  • Delayed and non-union
  • Wrist osteoarthritis

questions.text: Identify the fracture?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • A fracture involving the lateral condyle of the humerus. It is typically seen in children.

Causes
  • Most commonly by direct trauma to the elbow (Fall on the outstretched hand or a direct blow).
  • Torsional forces during activity or sports.

Types of Fractures
  • Type I: Non-displaced fractures (usually treated conservatively).
  • Type II: Displaced fractures (may require surgical intervention).
  • Type III: Comminuted fractures with significant displacement (often require surgery).

Symptoms
  • Pain and swelling around the lateral aspect of the elbow.
  • Limited range of motion, especially during extension and rotation.
  • Deformity or abnormal positioning of the elbow joint (in more severe cases).
  • Tenderness over the lateral condyle.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical examination: History of trauma, swelling, and deformity.
  • X-rays: To assess fracture type and displacement. Lateral and AP views are commonly taken.
  • CT scan: Can help evaluate complex fractures or assess joint involvement.

Treatment Options
  • Non-displaced fractures (Type I): Conservative management with rest, ice, and a sling or cast for immobilization.
  • Displaced fractures (Type II): Require surgical fixation, such as the use of pins or screws.
  • Comminuted fractures (Type III): Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF).

Complications
  • Elbow stiffness or loss of range of motion.
  • Malunion or improper healing, leading to angular deformity.
  • Post-traumatic arthritis due to joint surface involvement.
  • Nerve injury (Radial nerve) due to fracture or surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 7 year old boy is brought to the OPD. He fell on his outstretched arm while riding on his cycle. Clinical examination findings are presented in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Dorsal displacement supracondylar fracture of humerus

options.label: C
options.text: Malunion of a supracondylar fracture of humerus

questions.correct_answer: C. Malunion of a supracondylar fracture of humerus
questions.explanation:
Supracondylar Fractures

Mechanism of injury

Fall on outstretched hand (FOOSH)

Location

Humerus fractures just above the condyles.

Displacements

The distal fragment of the humerus is usually displaced by

  • Posterior shift (Due to Impaction)
  • Posterior Tilt
  • Proximal shift
  • Medial shift/ Tilt
  • Internal rotation

  • Type 2: Partially displaced fracture with displacement of only anterior cortex
  • Type 3: Completely displaced anterior and posterior cortex.

Clinical Presentation

  • Unusual posterior prominence of the olecranon in the backward tilt (S-shaped deformity)
  • The skin around the fracture has a dimpled appearance (Dimple sign)

  • Fat Pad or Sail sign: A translucent shadow-like appearance representing anterior and posterior fat pads.
  • Disturbed tear drop sign: An abnormal appearance of the fat pad, suggesting the presence of an injury, such as a fracture or joint effusion.

 

 

  • Fishtail sign: The ends of the proximal fragment are slightly widened and serrated, resembling a fishtail.
  • Crescent sign: The normal radiolucent gap of the elbow joint is replaced by a crescent-shaped shadow from the capitulum overlapping the olecranon, indicating varus or valgus tilt of the distal fragment.

Based on the type of fracture

  • Undisplaced fracture: Immobilisation in above-elbow plaster slab with the elbow in 90-degree flexion.
  • Displaced fractures
    • Closed reduction with percutaneous K-wire fixation. (for Type 2 fracture)
    • Open reduction internal fixation with K-wire. (for Type 3 fracture)

    • Dunlop traction (skin)
    • Smith traction (skeletal)

Complications

    • Vascular injury (commonly Brachial artery)
    • Nerve injury (commonly Anterior Interosseous nerve)
  • Delayed complications
    • Cubitus varus or Gunstock deformity (Malunion) (Option C)
    • Volkmann's Ischemia and compartment syndrome.
    • Elbow stiffness
    • Myositis ossificans.

questions.text: All of the following is seen in the terrible triad of elbow, except.

options.label: D
options.text: Fracture of the coronoid process of ulna

questions.text: In which of the following fractures does the three point bony relationship is maintained?
What is the name of the test performed in the image given below?

In the emergency room, a 40-year-old male patient arrived with a complaint of pain and swelling in the right shoulder region following a fall. The patient's X-ray indicates a tear in which of the following ligaments?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Acute acromioclavicular (AC) joint injury, commonly following direct trauma; includes sprains, subluxations, and dislocations.

Mechanism of Injury
  • Fall on the shoulder with arm adducted leading to ligament strain or tear. Severe forces may cause complete dislocation.

Classification
  • Type I: AC ligament sprain; joint remains undisplaced.
  • Type II: AC ligaments torn; joint subluxated with slight clavicle elevation.
  • Type III: AC and coracoclavicular ligaments torn; joint dislocated, visible step deformity. (Option C)
  • Type IV: Posterior clavicle displacement.
  • Type V: Marked upward clavicle displacement.
  • Type VI: Inferior clavicle displacement beneath the coracoid.

Clinical Features
  • Signs: Pain, bruising, and tenderness at the injury site. Visible ‘step’ in cases of dislocation.
  • Movement: Limited shoulder movement with severe pain in dislocation.

X-ray
  • Views: Anteroposterior, cephalic tilt, and axillary views are recommended. Stress view may differentiate Type II vs Type III.
  • Stress View: Measure the distance between the coracoid and clavicle; >50% difference indicates dislocation.

Treatment
  • Sprains/Subluxations: Rest in a sling, pain subsides within a week, followed by shoulder exercises.
  • Dislocations: Techniques include ligament reconstruction or clavicle excision.
  • Post-surgery Rehab: Elbow/forearm exercises day after surgery, shoulder movements 2 weeks later. Avoid strenuous lifting for 4–6 months.

questions.text: Which of the following ribs is fractured in the X-ray given below?

An 11-year-old patient presents with an outward angulation of the forearm in relation to the upper arm . The patient reports occasional discomfort and limitation in the range of motion of the affected arm. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct option B - Cubitus valgus Cubitus valgus Outward angulation of the forearm in relation to the upper arm Cubitus varus Inward angulation of the forearm in relation to the upper arm Gunstock deformity

  • Inward angulation of the forearm due to a malunion of the distal humerus after a fracture
  • The forearm appears bent, resembling the shape of a gunstock

Coxa vara Decrease in the angle between the head and neck of the femur leading to an inward angulation of the thigh bone

questions.text: The test performed in the following image is
Identify the following fracture?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Monteggia Fractu

Definition Monteggia Fracture is a type of forearm fracture involving a fracture of the proximal or middle third of the ulna with dislocation of the radial head. It was first described by Giovanni Battista Monteggia.
Anatomy Involved Fracture of the ulna (usually the proximal or middle third). - Dislocation of the radial head.
Mechanism of Injury Typically results from a direct blow to the forearm or a fall on an outstretched hand. - Force is transmitted along the forearm, causing the ulna fracture and radial head dislocation.
Clinical Presentation Deformity: Anterior angulation of the fractured ulna may be visible.- Pain: Localized pain at the site of the fracture and dislocation. - Limited Range of Motion: Restricted supination and pronation of the forearm.
Classification Bado Classification: Classifies Monteggia Fractures based on the direction of the radial head dislocation and associated ulna fracture pattern (Types I-IV).
Diagnostic Imaging X-rays of the forearm to visualize the fracture of the ulna and the dislocated radial head. - CT scans may be used for more detailed assessment.
Treatment Closed Reduction: Attempted for certain cases with early presentation and minimal displacement. - Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF): Surgical intervention may be required for more complex fractures or cases not amenable to closed reduction.
Complications Malunion: Improper alignment of the fractured bones. - Nonunion: Failure of the fractured bones to heal. - Radial Nerve Injury: Possible nerve injury associated with the fracture.
Rehabilitation Initiated post-surgery or after closed reduction to restore range of motion and strength. - Physical therapy is often a crucial component.

questions.explanation: Correct Option C - D

questions.text: The following images A and B show?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Jersey finger & baseball fing

Hand Injury

Explanation

Gamekeeper's Thumb

Injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the thumb, usually resulting from a forceful abduction or hyperextension of the thumb.

Mallet Finger

Injury to the extensor tendon of the finger, specifically at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. This injury is often caused by a forceful blow to the fingertip or by forcefully jamming the finger.

Jersey Finger

Injury to the flexor tendon of the finger, specifically at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. It occurs when the flexor tendon is torn or avulsed from its attachment to the bone, typically due to forceful extension of the finger while it is actively flexed, such as when trying to grab an opponent's jersey in sports.

Trigger Finger

A condition characterized by the inflammation and narrowing of the flexor tendon sheath in the finger.

Boxer's Fracture

A fracture of the metacarpal bone in the hand, specifically the neck of the metacarpal. It usually results from a direct impact with a closed fist, such as during a punch.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the condition known as "painful arc syndrome"?

options.label: A
options.text: A condition in which joint stiffness lasts for more than 30 minutes in the morning, affecting multiple joints.

options.label: B
options.text: A condition characterized by localized, sharp pain at the site of an injury or inflammation.

options.label: C
options.text: A condition where pain is experienced during a specific range of motion, typically between 60 and 120 degrees of shoulder abduction.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition marked by generalized musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points in various areas of the body.

questions.correct_answer: C. A condition where pain is experienced during a specific range of motion, typically between 60 and 120 degrees of shoulder abduction.
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - A condition where pain is experienced during a specific range of motion, typically between 60 and 120 degrees of shoulder abdu
